name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: [MUSIC]

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Text data is very special.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _In contrast to the data captured by machines such as sensors

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: text data is produced by humans.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And they also are meant to be consumed by humans.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And this has some interesting consequences.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Because it is produced by humans
column6: it tends to have a lot of useful knowledge about _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _people's' preferences
column6: people's' opinions about everything. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And that makes it possible to mine

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _text data to discover those latent prefaces of people

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: which could be very useful to build an intelligent system to help people.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: You can think about scientific literature or

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: so and it's a way to encode our knowledge about the world.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So it's very high quality content
column6: yet we have difficulty digesting all the content. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Now as a result of the fact that text is consumed by we humans

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _we also need intelligent software tools to help people digest the content
column6: or _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: otherwise we'd miss a lot of useful content.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: This slide shows that the human really plays important role in test data mining.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _We have to consider human in the loop
column6: and _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: we have to consider the fact that the text is generated by human.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So
column6: here are some examples of useful text information systems. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: This is by no means a complete list of all applications.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: I categorize them into different categories.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: But you can probably imagine other kinds of applications.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So let's take a look at some of them.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Search for example
column6: we all know search engines is special. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Web search engines
column6: iPad
column7: all of you are using Google

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: another web search engine all the time.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And we also have live research assistants.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And in fact
column6: wherever you have a lot of text data
column7: you would have a search engine. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So for example
column6: you might have a search box on your laptop. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _All right
column6: to search content on your computer. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So that's one kind of application systems
column6: but _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: we also have filtering systems or recommended systems.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Those systems can push information to users.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: They can recommend useful information to users.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So again
column6: use filters

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Literature the movie recommenders.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Now not of them are necessary recommending the information to you.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _For example email filter
column6: spam email filter

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _this is actually to filter out the spams from your inbox
column6: all right. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: But in nature these are similar systems in that they have to make a binary decision

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: regarding whether to retain a particular document or discard it.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Another kind of systems are categorization systems.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So for example
column6: in handling emails

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _you might prefer automatic
column6: sorter that would automatically _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: sort incoming emails into a proper folders that you created.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Or we might want to categorize product reviews into positive or negative.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: News agencies might be interested in

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: categorizing news articles into all kinds of subject categories.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Those are all categorization systems.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Finally there are also systems that might do more analysis.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And oh
column6: you can say mine text data. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And these can be text mining systems or

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _information extraction systems
column6: and they can be _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: used to analyze text data in more detail to discover potentially useful knowledge.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: For example companies might be interested in discovering

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _major complaints from their customers based on the email messages that the

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: they have received from the customers.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _All right
column6: so having a system to support that would _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: really help improve their productivity and the customer relations.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Also in business
column6: intelligence companies are often interested in analyzing product _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: reviews to understand the relative strengths of their own products

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: in comparison with competitors.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And
column6: and so these are all examples of these test mining systems. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: [INAUDIBLE] we have a lot of data in particular literature data.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So
column6: there's also great opportunity of using computer systems _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _to analyze the data to automatically read literature
column6: and _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _to gain knowledge
column6: and to help biologists make discoveries. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And you can imagine many others.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So the point is that with so much text data

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: we can build very useful systems to help people in many different ways.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Now how do we build this systems?

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Well these actually are the main technologies that we'll be talking

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: about in this course and the other course that I'm teaching for this specialization.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: The main techniques for building these systems and also for

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: harnessing the text data are text retrieval and text data mining.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So I use this picture to show the relation between these two

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: some of the different techniques.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _We started with big text data
column6: right? _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _But for any applications
column6: we don't necessarily need to use all the data. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Often we only need the small subset of the most relevant data
column6: and that's shown here. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So text retrieval is to convert big
column6: raw text data into that small _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: subset of most relevant data that are most useful for a particular application.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And this is usually done by search engines.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And so this will be covered in this course.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _After we have got a small amount of relevant data

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _we also need to further analyze the data to help people digest the data
column6: or _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: to turn the data into actionable knowledge.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And this step is called text mining
column6: where we use a number of techniques to _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: mine the data to get useful knowledge or pairings.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And the knowledge can then be used in many different applications.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And this part
column6: text mining
column7: will be covered in the other course that I'm _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: teaching called Text Mining and Analytics.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: The emphasis of this course is on basic concepts and

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: practical techniques in text retrieval.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: More specifically we will cover how search engines work.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: How to implement a search engine.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _How to evaluate a search engine
column6: so that you know one search engine is _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: better than another or one method is better than another.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: How to improve and optimize a search engine system.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And how to build a recommender system.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: We also hope to provide a hands on experience on multiple aspects.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: One is to create a test collection for evaluating search engines.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: This is very important for knowing which technique actually worked well.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And whether your search engine system is really good for your application.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: The other aspect is to experiment with search engine algorithms.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _In practice
column6: you will have to face choices of different algorithms. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So it's important to know how to compare them and

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _to figure out how they work or maybe potentially
column6: how to improve them. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And finally
column6: we'll provide a platform for you to do search engine competition. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Where you can compare your different ideas to see which idea works better

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: on some data set.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: The prerequisites for this course are minimum.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Basically we hope you have some basic concepts of computer science
column6: for _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: example data structures.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And we hope you will be comfortable with programming
column6: especially in C++. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: because that's the language that we'll use for some of the programming assignments.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _The format is lectures plus quizzes
column6: as often happens in MOOCs. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And we also will provide a program assignments for

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: those of you that have the resources to do that.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: We don't really have any required readings for this course.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _That just means if you follow all the lecture videos carefully

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: and you're suppose to know all the basic concepts and the basic techniques.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _But it's always useful to read more
column6: so _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: here we provide a list of some useful reference books.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And this in time order
column6: and that also includes a book that _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _and I are co-authoring now
column6: and _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: we make some draft chapters available on this website.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And we can find more readings and reference books on this website.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Finally
column6: and this is the course schedule. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _That's just the top of the map for the rest of the course

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: and it shows the topics that we will cover in the remaining lectures.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: This picture also shows basic flow of information in a text information system.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So starting from the big text data
column6: the first step is to do some natural language _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _content analysis
column6: because text data is in the form of natural language text. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So we need to understand the text to some extent

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: in order to do something useful for the users.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So this is the first topic that we will cover.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: And then on top of that as you can see there are two boxes here.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Those are two types of systems that can be used to help people

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: get access to the most relevant data.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Or in other words
column6: those are the two kinds of systems that will convert _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: big text data into small relevant text data.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Search engines are helping users to search or

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: to query the data to get the most relevant documents out.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Recommender systems are to recommend information to users

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: to push information to users.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So those are two
column6: complementary was of _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: getting users connected to the most relevant data at the right time.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _So this part is called text access
column6: and this will be the next topic. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And after we cover that we are going to cover a number of topics

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: all about the search engines.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _Now the text access topic is a brief topic

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: a brief coverage of the two kinds of systems.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _In the remaining topics
column6: we'll cover search engines in much more detail. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _That includes text retrieval problem
column6: text retrieval methods

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _these methods
column6: implementation of the system

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: _And after these
column6: we're going to go cover the recommender system. _

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: So this is what you expect in the rest of this course.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: Thanks.

name: 1 - 2 - Course Introduction (00-10-45).srt
text: [MUSIC]
